page.title: 04SUTTON PARK . WOODLAND
page.content: THE OLD WOODLANDS ARE BASICALLY OAK WITH SOME SILVER BIRCH AND ROWAN. THERE IS ALSO A REMARKABLY LUXURIANT UNDERSTORY OF HOLLY FOR WHICH THE AREA IS FAMOUS, THERE BEING FEW OTHER AREAS IN BRITAIN WHERE HOLLY IS SO ABUNDANT. THE GROUND FLORA OF THESE WOODS IS TYPICALLY HEALTHY AND INCLUDES BILLBERRY, COW-WHEAT AND WAVY HAIR-GRASS. THE OAKWOODS SUPPORT A VAST INSECT POPULATION AND PROVIDE NEST-SITES FOR BIRDS SUCH AS GREEN AND GREAT SPOTTED WOODPECKERS, NUTHATCHES, AND TREE CREEPERS. A NUMBER OF PLANTATIONS WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE PARK DURING THE 19TH AND EARLY 20TH CENTURIES. THE CHIEF SPECIES PLANTED ARE SCOTS PINE AND LARCH TOGETHER WITH CORSICAN PINE, SPRUCE, BEECH AND OAK.RHODODENDRONS OCCUR IN SEVERAL AREAS.
